I've had my 2017 model for several years now and liked it. So I decided to upgrade when I saw that there were deals on the 2020 version. I'm not so sure it was worth it. I currently own both of them and have had ample opportunity to compare them side by side. After several days of frustration have decided to vent my opinion in my review.

The new one has more memory to load apps and has a slightly faster processor so things run a little smoother. Those are good things, but there are many design changes which are not so nice.

The old one has the camera on the portrait side making it a little narrower and easier to handle, almost like holding a large phone, which is very nice for reading online books. The new one has the camera on the landscape side so the tablet is wider and unwieldy. You can't really figure out how to grip it and are almost forced to use a stand.

The screens have the same pixels but the 2020 version is darker and won't get as bright as the old one.

The 2017 sound quality was never great but the 2020 sound is even worse. It won't get as loud and sounds muffled, not nearly as crisp as the old one sounded.

However the most annoying thing to me are the power and volume buttons. On the 2017 model they projected out a nice distance so they were easy to feel, were silver colored so they were easy to see, and were spaced far apart so they were easy to find and not confuse between volume and power. On the 2020 version these buttons are reduced in height so you can't feel them, are now colored black so you can't see them, and are shoved closer together so you are not sure if you are on volume or power. You actually have to turn the tablet edge toward you to look at it so you can see which button you are pushing. This was clearly a design change for style with very little thought for functionality. To make it even worse the volume buttons have been programmed to switch position depending on the orientation of the tablet. If you are in landscape mode the top right button will be volume up. But if you turn the tablet to portrait mode the very same button becomes volume down! How silly is that? You never really know which way you are turning the volume until you see the volume tray pop up on the screen!

If this is your first tablet then this is not a bad one for the money. But if you are contemplating an upgrade move I would say that the annoyances outweigh the benefits. If Old Faithful is working fine I would say to forget about switching and just keep it.
summary: Not much improvement from 2017 model. Too many bad design changes.

I bought an Amazon Fire HDX 7 when it was first released nearly a decade ago. It was a stellar Kindle edition with a great screen, a comfortable feel and a burgeoning reputation as the best reading tablet on the market. Given that track history, I took a chance and upgraded to a Fire HD 8 in late January 2021. My buy-in wa predicated on the fact that Amazon would provide a $15 trade-in credit on my near-mint condition HDX 7. Long story short: Amazon rejected the HDX 7 trade-in and charged me the additional $15. Worse, they sent me an ad-supported HD 8 when I clearly had placed a slightly more expensive non-ad edition in my online cart. it subsequently cost me an additional $15 to cancel the ads showing up on the Fire HD 8 home screen.

As for the Fire HD 8 unit itself, there's not much to be overjoyed about. The software is fine but it's still Amazon-based and does not play well, if at all, with Mac or Android devices. The requisite Silk browser is several generations behind Google's Chrome or Apple's Safari. The screen is clear but, really, it looks and feels like a step backward from the HDX 7 screen. Also, the overall design of the unit in one's hands is a bit clunky. I have yet to sit and read with the unit held in my hands for any period longer than 10 minutes; invariably I need to prop it up on a pillow or set it against something.

In this owner's opinion, the Fire HD 8 is a Ford not a Mercedes.
summary: Fire HD 8 is solid Amazon product but a long way from a standout

CONS: I discovered to my dismay that all images opened in the default photo app only shows the image at a preview resolution, no matter the image size (WHY???). So I used a separate app and that allowed me to at least zoom in and see a crisp image with a tiny 1.8MB file size, but it takes a while to update. I don't know at what exact file size the device will decide it's too much and cap your image resolution. I tried 10MB-300MB lossless photos I had made. But when I zoomed in and waited for the screen to update, it still showed a very pixilated image. It could still be a limitation of the various apps I tried, but I find it troubling that in 2020-2021 the 8" Fire HD out-of-the-box makes me feel like tech is falling backwards and I'm stuck in the 90's, looking at pixilated image after image. To display and zoom into a 10MB-100MB image shouldn't be an issue today.

reviewText: I've got a few of these for portability. For the price, they're good little units. Get a nice protective cover, and you're set. My biggest issue with these tablets is the useless bloatware that is preinstalled, and not easily removed. There are online videos to go into developer mode to go in and remove some of it, but that's a hassle. So why do they insist on forcing you to keep garbage on your homepage you'll never use? They just take up memory, cache, and clog your performance. Not only that junk, but the splash screen ADs and game clickbait when you power it on. C'mon Amazon, we're not all 7 years old. Allow us to uninstall (instead of just forcing stops, clearing cache, and turning off notifications), and I'd go 5 stars. I do like the HD clarity though. I can actually see the faces of fans in the stands during a ballgame. That's pretty good for a small screen.

The battery life is paradoxically great, it will last for a long LONG time. Unfortunately however the Kindle inexplicably shuts off at random and will not power back on without being plugged in no matter what the charge level is, 40% - 90+% makes no difference. reviewText: If you have multiple kindles on your Amazon account you have no choice but to share your purchased books with every kindle. I can‚Äôt erase them from one kindle and keep on another. reviewText: This little tablet is fantastic! I was looking to replace my kindle fire 5th generation, which I was using primarily for videos and games. It provided many years of great service but was begging to retire! I nabbed this new Kindle and so far I am pleasantly surprised! The screen is slightly larger, and it is geared to be more for games and videos, so it seems like it is the best fit. I got the purple one, which gave an additional touch of pretty. Thankfully Amazon facilitates the transfer of data and information from tablet to another, so that was easy-peasy. the sound quality is sharp and clear, and the video quality is fantastic. The buttons are easy to access and are easy to find/ identify in the dark. I also added a memory card to expand the memory capacity. Anyone worried about the ads that come with the tablet should not give it a second thought; for the price it is really not troubling! Battery lasts a long time; I have used the tablet for about 4 hours at a time, streaming videos while I work and the battery is still in the high 90s%

I bought to this replace a Fire HD tablet I had for 4 or 5 years. The old one stopped charging. This new one is great all around except for a few annoyances. Whenever I watch an episode and finish, even if i click on the small next episode preview icon at the lower right that appears at the end of every episode, like "Watch next", it _always_ goes back to the first episode. And I have to scroll down and find the next episode and start it. My old Fire HD table never behaved that way. But that's what happens now. It also seems to sometimes randomly go back to the very beginning of the menu where you have to click into Prime Videos. That didn't happen before that I recall.

Also even though I have "turned off" location services and "alexa" there are 6 to 8 processes that continue to run that have names like Alexa ... whatever and Location (it's the name of the third party service they use for location services). That's not the end of the world, but if these are optional and disabled then why are these all still running on the device? Is it still actually recording everything it "hears" ? Other than those quirky things it's a great tablet.
summary: It always goes back to first episode

reviewText: I've never owned a tablet, but I've used them. It was the one gadget I never felt I needed. I always get a phone with a large screen and I have a laptop so the tablet felt pointless. But then I finally gave in. I took advantage of the Prime Day Deals and this little guy was at a real bargain price. I decided that the price, combined with the great Amazon return policy, was a good time to try one for myself. I'm very glad I did, this thing is more useful than I thought. Its light weight and the battery lasts a good while. I didn't need to charge it for over 3 days with my usage. It was easy to pickup and read emails and news without having to wait for it to boot up like my laptop. Plus its easier to walk around with, and way cheaper if I have an accidental drop, than if I was shuffling around with my laptop. It seems pretty snappy and it can run all my movie streaming services on it. My only complaint is the screen is highly reflective, in my opinion. It doesn't appear to have any sort of antiglare properties, or they are not good enough if it does. Its difficult to read while in the sun or even in a well light room. I also hate when a screen shows my reflection every time a movie scene is dark. I play with the angles to avoid direct lighting but its best viewed in the shade. Maybe you won't find this to be too bad, but for me its almost a deal breaker. Luckily I also own a few Kindle E-Readers, including the Oasis, so I just use those when I want to do some reading. This thing is impossible to read outdoors, its too much of a distraction for me, when I have to keep repositioning it to avoid reflections. Besides that, its a great little device and I've decided to keep it. It might be a gateway to an even better tablet, but for now it does everything I need.

For a device that portends to be a 'media and entertainment' I can't count on being able to use the apps that I got from the Amazon app store to work. While Netflix works okay, apps services that I have paid subscriptions for like Disney +, HBO/Max and others either don't open at all, gets stuck on the "Who's Watching?" screen or constantly shows an Error 43 code despite having a solid internet connection. I've spent hours on chat with Amazon and Disney + and it has probably only worked about 20% of the time despite numerous reinstalls and reboots. Their only advice was to reset the Fire to factory settings losing what I've already loaded.

There is also no way to easily access apps from Google Play, even the public library "Libby" app has to be accessed via online. Amazon App Store is limited at best.

I knew when I took advantage of the 'special offer' for the item that it wasn't an Apple iPad but I did expect it to do at least what it said it would. Should have listened to the reviews.
summary: Video apps like Disney + usually don't work when you want them to. Very disappointed.

reviewText:
I've long since decided that I'm not a tablet person. I have had Kindles which I use for reading, I have a Windows tablet and a Samsung Galaxy Note 8 tablet, the latter two have pretty much made me decide against tablets. The Windows tablet takes a bit too long to start up and it's slow and the screen iffy. The Samsung was okay until it updated to the latest OS at the time and that dropped battery life drastically. I never really used the pen input much either which is what I bought it for. I've been using my phone to play FV 2: Country Escape and lately it's been sluggish and unresponsive and I can't get the game to play on a Windows PC! For that reason alone when I saw the price had dropped during Amazon's Prime Day I decided to give it a try, also I have an old Kindle with no back lighting and I find books easier to read on my phone with small text because of the back lighting, so decided that I could get this to play FV and read e-books. Hopefully, at least from the bigger version, it seems that FV doesn't kill the battery as fast as on the phone.

It's a nice size to hold, not too big, not too small. The weight is okay, the screen is responsive. What I don't like is that pressing the screen doesn't wake it back up, I have to give a light press to the power button then swipe up to unlock from the ad page. I have Wyze cams and lots of Alexa devices but I wasn't able to view the Wyze cam on this so far. I don't even see a Wyze app in the app store, just generic IP camera apps.

I downloaded Netflix and it seems as if videos play well and are clear. I will update as time goes on and I get a better idea of its functionality, but so far it seems good for what I want it to do. Everything else I can do on my computer or phone.
summary: Bought to play FV: Country Escape!

reviewText:
Wow... even after just the first day of having this and comparing it to my older Fire 7 is like night and day! The Fire 7 was slow, sluggish, took what seemed like forever for apps to load/start. I had one streaming music app where I had to wait 5 minutes at times for the playlist to start playing. This thing? Instant. The way it should be.
The Fire 7 seemed to have wireless and bluetooth issues. Not this. But then, I'm starting to think there was just something wrong altogether with the Fire 7. It's now recently started freezing up and not running. And I've done factory resets on it several times to get it to work..
So, regardless of its issues.. this new Fire 8 is nice and fast and responsive. The wireless and bluetooth operate smoothly as they should. And I used the trade-in program using my older HDX 8.9. So I got rid of an old, outdated unit, and received a nice new one in its stead.

I cannot stress enough how much I wouldn't recommend this purchase. It may seem appealing given the low price for a decent sized tablet, but it has a myriad of issues and works so poorly I get stressed out every time I use it.

First, there is nearly zero support for this tablet. Almost no standard apple/android apps are available, even ones that should be a bare-minimum. Of the ones that *are* available, at least 75% of them just link you to the browser-based version of the app rather than a standalone app, and these rarely even work on amazon tablets (i.e. Discord, YouTube, etc).

Second, even the base-level functionality of the tablet is filled with glitches. You may not get a notification from any of your social media for months, then all of a sudden have 100+ notifications pop up at once at an indeterminate amount of time in the future. The software is also very laggy and I've had terrible connection issues that I'm certain aren't due to my internet provider (Google Fiber), and have troubleshooted otherwise.

Third, the tablet is riddled with ads. The entire lock screen is littered with so many that it is just plain obnoxious. Given the price, I could deal with this if the other issues weren't there, but as it stands it is unacceptable.

The only time I ever use this tablet is when I have literally no other devices to use at the time, and I still walk away frustrated from using it for as little as 30 minutes. I would not recommend it at all.

EDIT: Forgot to mention one of the worst features. Even with the tablet at 100% battery before completely shutting it off for the night, it will still somehow be dead by the morning. Makes me wonder what kind of apps they are running in the background even with it shut off.
summary: Terrible product, not even worth the low price

For the past ten years, I have been using an iPad. I mainly use a tablet for reading and saving my Kindle books, web browsing, a game here or there, storing photos, and probably some other small things like small notes. I'm sure there are some things I haven't mentioned, but those are the basics. After about a year ago I noticed that I wasn't able to get any more OS updates. The screen clarity is good enough for me and what I use it for. So I hope this information helps someone else in their decision.

I've had a few Kindles since the day they were 1st launched and I seriously read 1-2 full 400 page+ books per 1-1.5 days....EVERYDAY, cus I'm badass! reviewText: This Fire Tablet is the next generation HD8. The price (under $40) is great (not sure if it can still be ordered for that price). The screen resolution is excellent, ease of use as a handheld is great, and what ads pop up are not a big deal. Separately purchased a basic cover, and a simple screen saver pack to provide some protection. Did not purchase any extended warranty coverage since replacing would be inexpensive by comparison. The original order went astray, and we figured maybe porch pirates grabbed it. When it didn't show up we contacted amazon, a replacement was sent that arrived the next day. Of course, the following day the original showed up. Amazon provided no cost return shipping through UPS, and we sent it back. By the way, we liked it so much that we purchased a second one.

When I got this on sale and with Ibotta 5% cash back on the purchase of this tablet, it becomes seemingly an unbeatable deal.

This won‚Äôt match the iPad on any high end tablet. Where it beats most tablets is the price. Even the cheap unknown Chinese tablets you find on amazon aren‚Äôt this cheap, and with equal or if not worse specs.

Who is it for? People who are into the amazon ecosystem. I have prime, I have echoes. This makes sense to me. It can play all video services like Netflix or Hulu so it‚Äôs not just limited to amazon stuff. Can it do google play store? With an extra step yes and it works great that way. Millions of tutorials how, just make sure you know exactly which versions to get.

Setup was insane if not scary. Out of the box and turning it on, it already got into my wifi and amazon account logged in and ready to go. I‚Äôm guessing since I have echo devices already in place, alexa took care of the rest. Very cool...outside of feeling a bit violated

What I like: USB-C charger. That‚Äôs the future. Adapt or die. Speakers are also surprisingly good given the price. It‚Äôs also small and thin. Perfect for travel.

What I don‚Äôt like: screen is not great. But for 50 bucks it is. You get what you pay for.

Bottom line: this tablet is for multimedia consumption. Not really meant for hardcore games.

The big reason for me was to use it with Xbox xcloud and it works great once you load the play store. Totally worth it for that alone!

I am a long-time Kindle user. LONG TIME. I've bought a number of them for myself, given a few as gifts, and I have completely worn out several of them. (Can you tell I love Kindles?!) The most conspicuous difference is that I no longer can zoom by spreading my fingers on the touch screen. This is a real setback. In some functions (including a game I play on the tablet) with fonts set at the maximum size, I can barely read the print. This was easily dealt with on the old tablet but I have to use a magnifying glass on the new one. This is, in my opinion, a serious defect.

The other complaint I have is button placement. It is too easy to accidentally turn this off because of the placement of the power button as well as an onscreen one. This is a minor inconvenience but one the user has to learn to work around.

Battery life seems to be much better and there is a noticeable improvement in sharpness of images onscreen. This is a very reasonably priced device. I just wish it still had the capability to zoom images.

6/19/21 update. My order was within the 30 day return window, so I called customer service. They were top notch and they sent me a replacement right away. It came in today
and so far, so good. I will return the defective one next week. I am 100% satisfied with how Amazon has handled this. I am optimistic that my new Kindle will work as it is supposed to. If not, I will let y'all know. 6/15/21 update. I ended up resetting to factory settings. This fixed the continuous scrolling issue; HOWEVER, my Kindle turns off randomly and the only way I can turn it back on is to put it on the charger. I have three days to return it so I will contact customer service tomorrow to see if I can get a replacement. Buyer beware. I replaced my old Kindle Fire 8 because it stopped taking a charge. This one is very similar. My issue is that I accidentally turned on continuous scrolling. I want to to turn it off, but that option is not available. So, if you don't want continuous scrolling, be sure to NOT click on it.

I bought this to use as a remote control for a Roon playback system. It works well enough in that capacity, but the tablet runs an ancient version of Android that is severely out of date. It's a shame the Fire OS doesn't keep up with modern times and use an Android version that is way more secure, runs better, and has an improved interface over the old versions. Thankfully I was able to disable all of the Amazon apps using a USB cable and an ADB command line--it helped speed up this woefully underpowered tablet so it was usable. It's worth the $59.99 I paid for it, but not a penny more. It's outdated, both in hardware and OS. Good for a limited-use situation like mine, but I'd be afraid that others who expect it to be this spectacular multimedia device to run apps and watch movies on is going to be sorely disappointed.
summary: Good as a remote control, but not as a full-time tablet

Another thing to note, I didn't buy my Fire 8 HD from Amazon, I got it from HSN, where I also received a 32GB micro SD card and some productivity apps with my purchase and the best part was that I only paid about half-price off HSN.. so, to me, it was a bargain I couldn't pass up.

I had been using an ancient Samsung Galaxy Tab 10.1 tablet for several years for music, occasional video, and very rarely games; most apps would no longer work properly on it, so I knew that when Prime Day rolled around, I was going to get an upgrade. After a great deal of research, I picked the Fire HD 8, and after a few days of using it, I couldn't be happier with my choice.

I purchased the version with lockscreen ads, but I honestly don't even notice them, and couldn't tell you anything about a single one that I've seen. All of the major streaming apps for movies, television, and music are available in the Amazon Appstore, and most were already pre-loaded on the device. The screen is great for this price range--colors are bright, lines are sharp, and there's not really any pixilation. The device is extremely lightweight, and fits nicely in my hands. It's made of plastic, but it doesn't feel cheap like many other devices in this price range. The sound quality is also surprisingly good, so it can easily be used without external speakers or earbuds without sacrificing too much in terms of quality. Battery life seems about average so far.

There are only a very small handful of negatives. The screen seems to hold fingerprints and smudges much more easily than many other devices that I own. Furthermore, the device as a whole seems sluggish for the first few minutes after turning it on, although this doesn't seem to last for very long. Additionally, while the Amazon Appstore has basically everything I want for my purposes, there's nowhere near the variety of the Google Play Store or Apple App Store, so some people will definitely be missing things they want. Semi-related to the lack of Appstore offerings, the Silk browser that comes preinstalled is honestly pretty terrible, and seems to even have trouble properly processing things in Bing, which is its default search engine; I plan to rarely use this to surf the web, and set up Bing Rewards so I at least get something out of it if I feel that I need to do so, so this isn't as problematic for me as it may be for others.

Overall, this is a fantastic tablet at this price point. If you primarily want to stream music and video, or are looking for something inexpensive for a child, this is a great option. Unlike the other offerings in this price range (Onn and random Chinese brands), the screen quality and sound are great, and this doesn't feel cheap (I'd imagine that it's sold at cost or at a loss, primarily to encourage people to utilize Amazon services). If the Amazon Appstore were more robust--which would be doing consumers a favor by hitting the current duopoly, considering Apple is trying to build a "walled garden" they control entirely, and Google would like to do something similar (especially when Fuchsia rolls out to phones and tablets in two or so years)--I would honestly recommend this device to everyone who was looking for a tablet. That being said, this is easily the best device in this price range, and anyone considering a tablet, especially if they're primarily looking for a streaming device, should give the Fire HD 8 a look.
summary: Fantastic tablet, especially for the price

reviewText:
It's optimized for Amazon content--Ebooks purchased through Amazon, but you can also read other e-book content: I buy a number of e-books from different vendors, and use Calibre to manage my non-Amazon library. You can download those e-books to the 10th gen Kindle Fire, although having to re-enable file transfer every time you connect is clunky.

Of course, you can play games on the Kindle Fire! Most prior games that you purchased from the Amazon App Store will run fine.

I purchased this as a replacement for an earlier generation Kindle Fire, whose battery was beginning to age. The battery life on this one is just fine.

Some critiques:
(1) While it works fine for reading e-mail sent to gmail, I have not tested with other providers (such as Microsoft's "hotmail" service).
(2) The calendar app still does not integrate with Google Calendar. Just open up your Google Calendar using the browser (Silk), and bookmark your calendar app.
(3) The maps application is also poorly functional. Again, open the browser (Silk), open up your favorite mapping application, and bookmark your favorite mapping application.
(4) I don't like the new way that it organizes, with "For You," "Home," and "Library." Your apps, games, and other e-books are in "Library," and finding your downloaded books in "Library" is cumbersome.
(5) Changing the location of the rear camera makes this Fire incompatible with earlier generation cases. That's either "not paying attention," or intentional monetizing accessories. Bad!
summary: Think of it as an enhanced Kindle reader, not an Android tablet

Very disappointed that my security cam software (iztouch) I used on the 6th gen was no longer on the Amazon apps list, but after some pain I managed to find it on another site. When I got the 6th gen in 2016 I thought, "what do I need this for? Do I really need this? I was looking for something smaller than my laptop, and the Fire HD 8 seemed to fit the bill. And after using it for four years and noticing how much I use it every day for a bunch of reasons, the answer was a resounding yes. And when compared to the Chrome Book and iPad, I have to say the amount I paid for it was about 1/3 or 1/4 of what the others cost. Very much recommended to someone who wants something inexpensive that is a workhorse for many projects.
summary: Very Nice Particularly For The Money Compared to the competition

reviewText:
I definitely didn't have high expectations when buying a budget tablet. I never intended to play any games or watch HQ movies. The ONLY purpose that I had in mind was to use this to watch YouTube before going to bed.

With that being said, even with such low expectations, I am highly disappointed. The tablet lags terribly even with no simultaneous apps being open. From sleep to wake up, it lags so much that it takes a very long time when I try to open the YouTube app or even a browser. The buttons do not function during this time because it's trying to process the simple task of waking up. It might be a good device to train your patience, which I always fail to achieve.

All in all, I still use it to view YouTube videos because once it gets going, it's better. However, if I knew that this device would struggle with such simple tasks, I would never have purchased it even for a heavily discounted price during the holidays.
summary: Lags SO MUCH for such SIMPLE tasks

reviewText:
It's probably good for movies and other things, but I bought it to replace an old kindle that read my audiobooks while driving in the car. This device turns the speech off when I hit a bump or turn sharply, it has to be perfectly still to keep working. And the longest I can set the speech for is 30 minutes, I have a 45 min ride to work which means I would have to play with it while driving on the highway to keep it reading out loud.
I haven't figured out how to get internet on it when I'm not home or at work, so if a book ends mid trip I can't open another book until I get to my destination. I have figured out to open the next 2 or 3 ahead of time, hoping that works for next time.

reviewText:
I purchased this tablet primarily for reading eBooks. It integrates seamlessly with my Amazon account so my entire Kindle library transferred when I entered my Amazon account information. I also use it for reading recipes while I'm cooking, because my phone is too small and I hate bringing an expensive laptop so close to my disaster of a cooking procedure.

I picked the 8 over the 10 because I wanted it to remain close in size to my old kindle or a regular paper book. If you're looking for something to watch videos and play games, I would pick the 10. Although the screen is good sized, I wouldn't really want to watch a movie on it for an extended period of time. The 8's size is perfect for reading books, and it easily slips into my purse.

One improvement I would like to see is that when you ask Alexa to search for such and such recipe, it only pulls up recipes from Allrecipes.com. I want it to pull up everything it can find on the web so I can scroll through it. The "Reading Mode" feature when using the web browser also seems picky, and I can't get it to remain open indefinably when I'm reading a recipe. This good be user ignorance, too.

I traded in my 7th generation fire tablet for one of these because I was getting frustrated with the slow response, short battery life, and small storage (yes, I know you can use an SD card, but even that presents problems). I was pleasantly surprised to see that this one was noticeably better in all areas. The bigger screen makes it better for movies or web browsing, though not too big that it's cumbersome to handle. The battery lasts days now as opposed to minutes. It will even give you an estimate as to how much longer the battery will last on its current charge, or when plugged in, how long until fully charged. The processor is so much faster and the loading times for opening apps is significantly improved. It even has a game mode that will shut down all other apps to allow for more processing power to the game your playing. The bigger hard drive means there may not be a need for you to expand the storage, but I still use the SD card slot to transfer movies from my computer, so I'm glad it's still there.

If you're familiar with Amazon products (especially FireTV) you know that they are generally intended for people within the Amazon ecosystem (Amazon Prime and/or Amazon purchases). So when you scroll you "Your movies," it's not going to be movies on your device, or even streaming services you subscribe to. It'll simply movies available on Amazon Prime, regardless of whether or not you subscribe. Same with music, books, etc. While it does make it feel like you're only using 2/3 of your device's full potential, it's not intrusive to the point that it becomes frustrating, and not to the point that I felt the need to remove a star.

Amazon has made huge improvements to their tablets, and this is the one to get if you're on the fence.

Considering the cost, this tablet performs fairly well. Those purchasing this tablet should not compare it to tablets made by Apple or Samsung, and it is important to keep in mind that this is really a Fire OS device, not Android. Yes - Fire OS is based on Android; but not the same - a hack is required to run Android apps and even with that they are not guaranteed to run 100% effectively. In short, apps by Google are not available on this app, smart home apps (not designed to work with Alexa), password managers, and other apps will not be available on the Fire Tablet. Overall, this is the perfect app for content consumption - those just needing a browser, those looking to watch Prime videos/movies, content on Netflix or Disney+, etc‚Ä?There are gaming apps as well; but most are not graphic intense. I also question the build quality, thinking back at the Nexus tablets that were released years ago, it seems like Amazon could have built these a bit better for the cost. Personally, I feel as if Amazon should switch to Android tablets. I know that they want to keep people in their ecosystem; however, with not many making Android tablets, this would make them more appealing and useful to many more people.

I got the 7in and about a month later I upgraded to the 8in HD. I'm so glad I did. The battery life is way better, the size and weight are great. With the 7, I had to charge it once a day. If I wasn't using it, it would just die. Not the 8. I can use it for a couple of days and be fine.
This charges with a USB-C, which all my devices charge with, so it's easy to find a charger. It acts as an Alexa, so if you don't want to get the Alexa device and just prop the Fire 8 on a stand, it's perfect for that as well. The processor on this is not much faster, but fast enough that I feel a lot better using it.
My only con is the speakers. I didn't expect them to be great, but the volume is so low even when at its highest setting. I don't mind using headphones, but I like to fall asleep to a good book, but I can't hear as well.
Totally worth the upgrade though.
summary: I upgraded from the 7 to the 8 and I love it.

I waited to write this review until I could adjust to the unexpected changes in moving to the 8" HD. In the beginning changes can be frustrating until you get used to them then decide if they are for better or worse.

Overall, I think this is a great device with only one or two dings after getting used to the changes. I love the larger screen, increased sound quality with two speakers and the extra memory. And I'm still finding new helpful functions on the device.

Things I've adjusted to:
As for navigation, I now only have For You, Home and Library tabs instead of the Home, Books, Games,etc. I asked why in the beginning but now like having the one screen to see each category. On the flip side unless I'm missing something, instead of going to Books tab then having the Store option, I have to go to Library, Show More, Open Kindle then I'm at the Store button. A lot more steps.

The speakers are both on the left side of the device which really annoyed me at first. The sound quality is great but was out of balance when holding upright. Nice and loud for left ear but much quieter for right one. But I've adjusted to it so much that I don't really notice it anymore.

Still don't like:
The moving of the power button to the left side on top of the device putting it right next to the volume buttons. This might sound minor but I can't count the number of times that I've reached to change the volume and hit power button. They are that close especially when doing it by feel. To add to the issue, the up and down volume buttons are so close they feel like a single button.

So I've adjusted to all the changes and really appreciate the 8"HD except for that Power button location. Also I absolutely love the Alexa Device Dashboard icon on the bottom navigation bar.

My 4th Fire, ordered on Prime Day, and the first one to have problems this soon. I have a LOT of Kindle books, but my Library keeps disappearing on the new device. Of course those books are in the cloud, but that does me no good if I can't access them on the device! When this happens, the last book I opened may show up, or may not. reviewText:
I bought an Amazon Fire HDX 7 when it was first released nearly a decade ago. It was a stellar Kindle edition with a great screen, a comfortable feel and a burgeoning reputation as the best reading tablet on the market. Given that track history, I took a chance and upgraded to a Fire HD 8 in late January 2021. My buy-in wa predicated on the fact that Amazon would provide a $15 trade-in credit on my near-mint condition HDX 7. Long story short: Amazon rejected the HDX 7 trade-in and charged me the additional $15. Worse, they sent me an ad-supported HD 8 when I clearly had placed a slightly more expensive non-ad edition in my online cart. it subsequently cost me an additional $15 to cancel the ads showing up on the Fire HD 8 home screen.

As for the Fire HD 8 unit itself, there's not much to be overjoyed about. The software is fine but it's still Amazon-based and does not play well, if at all, with Mac or Android devices. The requisite Silk browser is several generations behind Google's Chrome or Apple's Safari. The screen is clear but, really, it looks and feels like a step backward from the HDX 7 screen. Also, the overall design of the unit in one's hands is a bit clunky. I have yet to sit and read with the unit held in my hands for any period longer than 10 minutes; invariably I need to prop it up on a pillow or set it against something.

In this owner's opinion, the Fire HD 8 is a Ford not a Mercedes.
summary: Fire HD 8 is solid Amazon product but a long way from a standout

CONS: I discovered to my dismay that all images opened in the default photo app only shows the image at a preview resolution, no matter the image size (WHY???). So I used a separate app and that allowed me to at least zoom in and see a crisp image with a tiny 1.8MB file size, but it takes a while to update. I don't know at what exact file size the device will decide it's too much and cap your image resolution. I tried 10MB-300MB lossless photos I had made. But when I zoomed in and waited for the screen to update, it still showed a very pixilated image. It could still be a limitation of the various apps I tried, but I find it troubling that in 2020-2021 the 8" Fire HD out-of-the-box makes me feel like tech is falling backwards and I'm stuck in the 90's, looking at pixilated image after image. To display and zoom into a 10MB-100MB image shouldn't be an issue today.

reviewText: I've never owned a tablet, but I've used them. It was the one gadget I never felt I needed. I always get a phone with a large screen and I have a laptop so the tablet felt pointless. But then I finally gave in. I took advantage of the Prime Day Deals and this little guy was at a real bargain price. I decided that the price, combined with the great Amazon return policy, was a good time to try one for myself. I'm very glad I did, this thing is more useful than I thought. Its light weight and the battery lasts a good while. I didn't need to charge it for over 3 days with my usage. It was easy to pickup and read emails and news without having to wait for it to boot up like my laptop. Plus its easier to walk around with, and way cheaper if I have an accidental drop, than if I was shuffling around with my laptop. It seems pretty snappy and it can run all my movie streaming services on it. My only complaint is the screen is highly reflective, in my opinion. It doesn't appear to have any sort of antiglare properties, or they are not good enough if it does. Its difficult to read while in the sun or even in a well light room. I also hate when a screen shows my reflection every time a movie scene is dark. I play with the angles to avoid direct lighting but its best viewed in the shade. Maybe you won't find this to be too bad, but for me its almost a deal breaker. Luckily I also own a few Kindle E-Readers, including the Oasis, so I just use those when I want to do some reading. This thing is impossible to read outdoors, its too much of a distraction for me, when I have to keep repositioning it to avoid reflections. Besides that, its a great little device and I've decided to keep it. It might be a gateway to an even better tablet, but for now it does everything I need.

For a device that portends to be a 'media and entertainment' I can't count on being able to use the apps that I got from the Amazon app store to work. While Netflix works okay, apps services that I have paid subscriptions for like Disney +, HBO/Max and others either don't open at all, gets stuck on the "Who's Watching?" screen or constantly shows an Error 43 code despite having a solid internet connection. I've spent hours on chat with Amazon and Disney + and it has probably only worked about 20% of the time despite numerous reinstalls and reboots. Their only advice was to reset the Fire to factory settings losing what I've already loaded.

There is also no way to easily access apps from Google Play, even the public library "Libby" app has to be accessed via online. Amazon App Store is limited at best.

I knew when I took advantage of the 'special offer' for the item that it wasn't an Apple iPad but I did expect it to do at least what it said it would. Should have listened to the reviews.
summary: Video apps like Disney + usually don't work when you want them to. Very disappointed.

reviewText:
Wow... even after just the first day of having this and comparing it to my older Fire 7 is like night and day! The Fire 7 was slow, sluggish, took what seemed like forever for apps to load/start. I had one streaming music app where I had to wait 5 minutes at times for the playlist to start playing. This thing? Instant. The way it should be.
The Fire 7 seemed to have wireless and bluetooth issues. Not this. But then, I'm starting to think there was just something wrong altogether with the Fire 7. It's now recently started freezing up and not running. And I've done factory resets on it several times to get it to work..
So, regardless of its issues.. this new Fire 8 is nice and fast and responsive. The wireless and bluetooth operate smoothly as they should. And I used the trade-in program using my older HDX 8.9. So I got rid of an old, outdated unit, and received a nice new one in its stead.

I cannot stress enough how much I wouldn't recommend this purchase. It may seem appealing given the low price for a decent sized tablet, but it has a myriad of issues and works so poorly I get stressed out every time I use it.

First, there is nearly zero support for this tablet. Almost no standard apple/android apps are available, even ones that should be a bare-minimum. Of the ones that *are* available, at least 75% of them just link you to the browser-based version of the app rather than a standalone app, and these rarely even work on amazon tablets (i.e. Discord, YouTube, etc).

Second, even the base-level functionality of the tablet is filled with glitches. You may not get a notification from any of your social media for months, then all of a sudden have 100+ notifications pop up at once at an indeterminate amount of time in the future. The software is also very laggy and I've had terrible connection issues that I'm certain aren't due to my internet provider (Google Fiber), and have troubleshooted otherwise.

Third, the tablet is riddled with ads. The entire lock screen is littered with so many that it is just plain obnoxious. Given the price, I could deal with this if the other issues weren't there, but as it stands it is unacceptable.

The only time I ever use this tablet is when I have literally no other devices to use at the time, and I still walk away frustrated from using it for as little as 30 minutes. I would not recommend it at all.

EDIT: Forgot to mention one of the worst features. Even with the tablet at 100% battery before completely shutting it off for the night, it will still somehow be dead by the morning. Makes me wonder what kind of apps they are running in the background even with it shut off.
summary: Terrible product, not even worth the low price

The charger is not usable, but with the USB-C cord and with one of the many chargers we all accumulate, it does well charging, signals with a chime when it begins. Battery life is less compared with 1st generation and kindle white.

I spend time reading every day and thought this type of product was a worthless trend. I've used a different product for the last two years having bought it to have a larger selection of reading material than readily available in the small rural town in which I live.

It was good. I was happy with it. I dropped it in the tub twice, but dried it out quickly with rice and silicate packages. Still, it has been acting up lately...months later. So, I bought this one.

It's OUTSTANDING! Fast, precise, 12hr battery life, crisp clear and brilliant color presentation, Alexa-compatible. I highly recommend it.

For the past ten years, I have been using an iPad. I mainly use a tablet for reading and saving my Kindle books, web browsing, a game here or there, storing photos, and probably some other small things like small notes. I'm sure there are some things I haven't mentioned, but those are the basics. After about a year ago I noticed that I wasn't able to get any more OS updates. Without the latest OSX versions you aren't able to download apps like Netflix or YouTube (there are the other things I use a tablet for). Also, websites aren't maximized for an unsupported Safari browser. I looked at the Fire and Apple tablets. For what I use a tablet for the price of an iPad is crazy. For almost a fraction of the cost, it was a no-brainer.

The Fire HD 8 with screen-lock adds is great. I did go back and forth about if I was going to get the 8" screen or the 7" screen. I ended up going with the 8". I made some changes to the main screen interface through the use of the "Developer tools", and added "Google Play". So, I get a little more true Android functionality out of it. So I still have all of the Amazon apps and I can add things that aren't offered through the AppStore. The screen size is great, I didn't want to carry around a 10" tablet again. The screen clarity is good enough for me and what I use it for. So I hope this information helps someone else in their decision.

I've had a few Kindles since the day they were 1st launched and I seriously read 1-2 full 400 page+ books per 1-1.5 days....EVERYDAY, cus I'm badass! With this point I honestly think I have a pretty good opinion on Kindles. I have difficulty with my eyesight that made me decide to try digital reading and this kindle is, so far, the best model I have found, out of what is currently available for 2020. My eyes stutter along the words if they show up on a white page in black font. I found the setting, in the Fire Kindle HD, that allows you to have it in a Dark Mode where the backscreen is black and the text is white. This setting reduces my migraines and eye stutter so much that I went from refusing to read anything and almost despising books to reading every single day as well as writing my own novels!

Also, I really rely on the cover art as much as the book description when choosing my next read. If using an Oasis or any other Kindle model like it(Paperwhite), everything is black and white. This severely reduces certain details in artwork, sometimes part of the artwork disappears completely when converted to black and white. I know this is really sounding picky and bitchy but, having the artwork in color is so effective in grabbing my attention and pulling me in!

I also found this Kindle Fire HD8 to be quick, easy to use and worked well with the "Alexa" software compared to other, older, models I've had. I loved the huge library space and thin more ergonomic feel and weight of the device. I really recommend this model, it's eye opening! <see what I did there? LOL
summary: Honestly returned my Kindle Oasis for this! It's really more worth it!

reviewText:
Great product. This is my 5th or 6th Kindle Fire & was a gift for my 93 yo mother-in-law who has vision problems. We both love our Kindles.

Amazon didn't like my 1st review because they think it contained feedback it doesn't allow. It doesn't. Actually, if a person saw my review they'd see it asks a question, one that I haven't been able to get an answer to.

I don't care if you don't post this, but I would like someone in Amazon to get back to me with an answer.
summary: Great product, but why couldn't I buy it directly from Amazon?

reviewText: This Fire Tablet is the next generation HD8. The price (under $40) is great (not sure if it can still be ordered for that price). The screen resolution is excellent, ease of use as a handheld is great, and what ads pop up are not a big deal. Separately purchased a basic cover, and a simple screen saver pack to provide some protection. Did not purchase any extended warranty coverage since replacing would be inexpensive by comparison. The original order went astray, and we figured maybe porch pirates grabbed it. When it didn't show up we contacted amazon, a replacement was sent that arrived the next day. Of course, the following day the original showed up. Amazon provided no cost return shipping through UPS, and we sent it back. By the way, we liked it so much that we purchased a second one.

When I got this on sale and with Ibotta 5% cash back on the purchase of this tablet, it becomes seemingly an unbeatable deal.

This won‚Äôt match the iPad on any high end tablet. Where it beats most tablets is the price. Even the cheap unknown Chinese tablets you find on amazon aren‚Äôt this cheap, and with equal or if not worse specs.

Who is it for? People who are into the amazon ecosystem. I have prime, I have echoes. This makes sense to me. It can play all video services like Netflix or Hulu so it‚Äôs not just limited to amazon stuff. Can it do google play store? With an extra step yes and it works great that way. Millions of tutorials how, just make sure you know exactly which versions to get.

Setup was insane if not scary. Out of the box and turning it on, it already got into my wifi and amazon account logged in and ready to go. I‚Äôm guessing since I have echo devices already in place, alexa took care of the rest. Very cool...outside of feeling a bit violated

What I like: USB-C charger. That‚Äôs the future. Adapt or die. Speakers are also surprisingly good given the price. It‚Äôs also small and thin. Perfect for travel.

What I don‚Äôt like: screen is not great. But for 50 bucks it is. You get what you pay for.

Bottom line: this tablet is for multimedia consumption. Not really meant for hardcore games.

The big reason for me was to use it with Xbox xcloud and it works great once you load the play store. Totally worth it for that alone!

I am a long-time Kindle user. LONG TIME. I've bought a number of them for myself, given a few as gifts, and I have completely worn out several of them. (Can you tell I love Kindles?!) I recently wore out my "Fire HD8", and had to replace it ASAP because it was my favorite (size, usability, portability, etc.) I am not totally happy with the replacement - latest edition. Battery power seems okay, but across the board and I can't say why exactly, but It simply is not up to par with the previous Fire HD8s.

"New Edition". "Enhanced". "Improved". BS. ALL words to dupe consumrs into paying for a more expensive product. Seems any one of them that really really works well and suits users to a T, will never be the same and definitely will ot be 'better'. Companies will be riding on the popularity of the first ones' coattails while reducing some bits that we consumers can't actually pinpoint, just to save them money and make their profits higher. It happens. Totally.Disgusting.
summary: Sure not what they used to be!

reviewText:
My older kindle is starting to run battery down quickly so I thought I would get a spare when they were on sale. Ordered this one and paid extra to not have adds on it. Well got it and found there is no way to get all the added stuff "encouraging" you to spend more money off the home page. I can't imagine how much more would have been on there if I hadn't paid for no adds. It's just annoying to have a ton of things on it I have no interest in and can't remove.

Seemed to work fine though I only had it on for short period before deciding to return it. I found an used HDX that I got and paid more for than this one but like it so much better. I only have what I want on it and removed everything else that was taking up space.

When I can't find old ones anymore I'll have to switch to a different brand as I really don't like the added things.

Saw this device on sale so took the plunge. Granted it's a sub-$100 device so not much expectation. I had installed Google Play Store so that I can play some games as my ipad mini 2 needs to retire from 7 years of service as the battery doesn't last over 3 hours.

To my surprise, the same games were loading/running at the same speed as my ipad mini 2. I was hoping for a faster load time experience but no such luck. At least the games don't crash as often as the ipad. It could be the android vs ios platform as well. To give a perspective, iphone 11 loads the game in 12 seconds whereas this kindle fire 8 takes 26 seconds to load.

I also compared speed with the 2017 Fire HD 10" and load times were about the same for the same apps.

PROS:
- low price - I didn't even buy a screen protector for the device
- Amazon apps run fine (kindle books, video, shopping)
- USB-C charging - finally don't have to look at the charging port to make sure to stick in the cable in the correct direction
- microsd expansion
- allows you to install Google Play Store
- good battery life (lasts all day)

CONS:
- screen resolution is not full HD so you do see the pixels
- extreme slow speed when running Google Play Store apps
summary: Runs as fast as my ipad mini 2 from 2014 :(

reviewText:
This still uses a slow charging, 5 watts I believe so it takes forever to charge. For no good reason.
As far as the slow performance its not surprising considering the only 2GB of RAM but I bet it'd be better off if we were actually able to get rid of the 10GB of bloating software that it comes with.
The Ads and constant amazon content being shoved upon you is insane. I bought the no ad version and you guys just cannot provide a product without forcing ads and Amazon content down the users throat.
And don't forget you can indeed install Google Play Store and thus whatever apps you want, just look it up online. Its really not that bad to do.
In the end its useful as a reader and utilities. Frustratingly slow for browsing the web or watching videos. Also the positioning of the buttons and speakers (as well as quality) are questionable.

After inadvertantly leaving my old Fire tablet on a plane I found myself ordering this HD 8 as a replacement and have noted a few differences.

The most conspicuous difference is that I no longer can zoom by spreading my fingers on the touch screen. This is a real setback. In some functions (including a game I play on the tablet) with fonts set at the maximum size, I can barely read the print. This was easily dealt with on the old tablet but I have to use a magnifying glass on the new one. This is, in my opinion, a serious defect.

The other complaint I have is button placement. It is too easy to accidentally turn this off because of the placement of the power button as well as an onscreen one. This is a minor inconvenience but one the user has to learn to work around.

Battery life seems to be much better and there is a noticeable improvement in sharpness of images onscreen. This is a very reasonably priced device. I just wish it still had the capability to zoom images.

6/19/21 update. My order was within the 30 day return window, so I called customer service. They were top notch and they sent me a replacement right away. It came in today
and so far, so good. I will return the defective one next week. I am 100% satisfied with how Amazon has handled this. I am optimistic that my new Kindle will work as it is supposed to. If not, I will let y'all know. 6/15/21 update. I ended up resetting to factory settings. This fixed the continuous scrolling issue; HOWEVER, my Kindle turns off randomly and the only way I can turn it back on is to put it on the charger. It was in a protective case, and I thought maybe it was overheating, so I took it out. The next day it turned off again. I have three days to return it so I will contact customer service tomorrow to see if I can get a replacement. Buyer beware. I replaced my old Kindle Fire 8 because it stopped taking a charge. This one is very similar. My issue is that I accidentally turned on continuous scrolling. I want to to turn it off, but that option is not available. So, if you don't want continuous scrolling, be sure to NOT click on it.

I bought this to use as a remote control for a Roon playback system. It works well enough in that capacity, but the tablet runs an ancient version of Android that is severely out of date. It's a shame the Fire OS doesn't keep up with modern times and use an Android version that is way more secure, runs better, and has an improved interface over the old versions. Thankfully I was able to disable all of the Amazon apps using a USB cable and an ADB command line--it helped speed up this woefully underpowered tablet so it was usable. It's worth the $59.99 I paid for it, but not a penny more. It's outdated, both in hardware and OS. Good for a limited-use situation like mine, but I'd be afraid that others who expect it to be this spectacular multimedia device to run apps and watch movies on is going to be sorely disappointed.
summary: Good as a remote control, but not as a full-time tablet

reviewText:
I'm usually a positive person so let's start with the good points: this was a gift and I'm extremely grateful. The Alexa features are always fantastic on every Amazon device I purchase and they are great on this device as well.

Compared to my Apple tablet. this product is slow, heavy, and has very limited apps. This replaced my Apple product so I find it a little inconvenient at times that I can't do as much on it as I was able to with my iPad. Also, the advertisements that constantly pop up and ding can be a annoying in the middle of the night so I end up turning off the tablet after every use. The only solution I found online is to pay $15 through Amazon to stop the advertisement (which honestly might be worth it, though it's a rip off).

Despite my preferences, this is the perfect product for basic music listening, kindle reading, and online movie/ TV show watching. Though searching the web is slow, streaming is great!

In the end, I really want to like this tablet but unfortunately, comparing this to other products out there, I'm not sure if I would recommend this one.

It's a high quality tablet, they do everything a tablet is supposed to do and they do it well. Everything but last, you'll be buying a new one every two years or so. I have 5 of these...3 HD 8's a 10 and a 7 ....my 7 still works great, slow, but decent for what I paid for it, but it's screen resolution and sound are of mediocre quality. The 8's and the 10 are great, and every one I've had dies in about 2 years. Planned obsolescence at it's highest form. Buy a better one or be prepared to pay $35 a year for the privilege of paying $130 more for Prime. I'm rethinking my online entertainment provider and I'm not buying any more Fire tablets... It's too bad too, they really are well done but the batteries just die too soon no matter how you treat them.

I own three other Kindles. You changed the charging cord with a different plug into the Kindle. It is not compatible with the other 3 charging plugs. The settings controls have been changed. When I down swipe to connect to Wi-Fi, I get a totally different picture. My other Kindles will show what connections are available if I tap the Wi-Fi icon. The new Kindle 8 only shows I am connected, if I tap it I get nothing. I tried to change the settings to show the connection and other available connections. I was unable to accomplish what I wanted. The reality is that the need to have intuitive knowledge to set up the Kindle sucks. You need a comprehensive user manual. The help function is worthless. In spite of their short comings, I still own 4 Kindles. There is significant utility in their operation.

I had my previous Kindle Fire for 7 years before it completely stopped working. Decided to look into the new tablets and was pleased to find out how affordable this tablet was along with with size. Now that I have the product and use it every single day all I can say is it is such good quality. All the functions are super easy to control, and there is plenty of storage for all the apps I desire. The only downfall I have found after having it for almost a month is the aux jack is weird and I have to push or pull my earbuds to get it in or out of the jack to the point where I feel like I am going to break my earbuds.

I bought it as an upgrade to my Fire 7. Slightly bigger than the 7, the screen is better, the colors do pop on this and the sound is very good too. The extra 16GB of memory is always helpful, I can put a lot of books on this device (not that I couldn't on my 7). Despite it's size, it's actually very comfortable to hold for even long periods of time and my wrists don't ache. I will say the battery life is great on this, I've left it unplugged for days and still never had it drop below 60%, fast charging too.

I'm very happy with it. I don't play too many games on it though, so I really can't comment on whether or not it's good for those. Another thing to note, I didn't buy my Fire 8 HD from Amazon, I got it from HSN, where I also received a 32GB micro SD card and some productivity apps with my purchase and the best part was that I only paid about half-price off HSN.. so, to me, it was a bargain I couldn't pass up.
